questions.text: Which type of splint is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bohler Braun Splint Bohler-Braun splint: This is a frame that has several pulleys (1-3) over which the traction cord passes while giving traction for different fractures. It is more convenient than Thomas's splint since it has no ring. The ring of a Thomas splint is a common cause of discomfort, especially in elderly people. A Bohler-Braun splint has no inbuilt system of counteraction, hence it is not suitable for transportation.

Highyeild:

Bohler Braun splint This splint has got various pulley's which can be used to create pull in different directions. Although it is bulky and cannot be used for transportation of the patient, but it is more convenient than thomas splint as it need not be passed across the limb.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. A Thomas splint is used for immobilization of the lower limb. The ring of the Thomas splint is introduced around the limb. The thigh and leg are supported on slings tied over the sidebars. Option: C. Gallow’s traction is used for fracture shaft of the femur in children less than 2 years of age Option: D. Cramer-wire splint: This splint is used for temporary splinting of fractures during transportation. It is made up of two thick parallel wires with interlacing wires. It can be bent into different shapes to immobilize different parts of the body.

questions.text: What is the plate shown in the figure below?

options.label: B
options.text: LC DCP(Limited Contact Dynamic Compression Plate)

questions.explanation:
Solution:

DCP (Dynamic Compression Plate) DCP is used for compression plating of long bones like the radius, ulna, humerus, and femur. DCPs should be differentiated from LCDCPs based on their shape and other features as shown in the table below. DCP (Dynamic Compression Plate) - used for compression plating of long bones like the radius, ulna, humerus, and femur

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. LC DCP (Limited Contact Dynamic Compression Plate) – similar to DCP plates, but has a low footprint compared to DCP plates. LCDCPs have the advantage of not hampering the periosteal blood supply in comparison to DCP. DCP IC DCP Undercuts Absent PRESENT Hole distance Even UNEVEN Bending force distribution Even UNEVEN Cross section and stiffness Minimum at plate hole UNIFORM Blood supply More affected MINIMALLY AFFECTED Bone ingrowth at fracture site Less MORE Stress riser Less LESS Stress shielding More LESS Lag screw placement freedom 2.5 longitudinal and 7 sideway 40 LONGITUDINAL AND 7 SIDEWAY Option: C. LCP (Locking Compression Plate) – Plates with locking slots, fixed angle rigid construct. Option: D. External Fixator – Apparatus used mainly in open fractures, has a connecting rod and shank pins holding the fracture fragment.

questions.text: Which surgical instrument is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Needle holder It has smaller blades with serrated inner surfaces. It has a small longitudinal groove to hold the shaft of the needle. They are attached with a locking mechanism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Artery (hemostatic) forceps are Conical and blunt-tipped blades with serrated inner margins. Option: C. Allis forceps have straight blades with sharp interlocking teeth and are fitted with a catch-lock system. Option: D. Towel clips have small, curved, and sharply pointed blades and are Given with a catch-lock mechanism.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Allis forceps Allis forceps have straight blades with sharp interlocking teeth, Fitted with a catch-lock system. Uses: Used to hold tough structures such as skin, fascia, capsule, etc.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Kocher Forceps is a heavy instrument designed to aggressively grasp medium to heavy tissue or occlude heavy, dense vessels. They have horizontal serrations the entire length of the jaw as well as 1 X 2 teeth at the tip. Option: B. Artery (hemostatic) forceps is a Conical and blunt-tipped blade with serrated inner margins. Option: C. Needle holder It has smaller blades with serrated inner surfaces. It has a small longitudinal groove to hold the shaft of the needle They are attached with a locking mechanism.

questions.text: What surgical instrument is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bone nibbler Parts: –– Handpiece with spring action. –– Hinge- single or double action. –– Cupped blades with sharp edges. Variation: Straight or curved. Uses: = used for nibbling the bone. The double action reduces the force required for cutting the bone

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Bone lever Parts: Handle with a ring A blade with a variation like Š. Straight or curved: Curved levers confine the curvature of the bone. Š. Smooth or serrated: Serrated levers prevent slippage over the periosteum Uses: Retraction of soft tissue during surgeries over long bone. Option: C. Osteotome Part: Blunt flat top. Handle. Quadrangular shaft—flattened and both edges beveled. Variations: Straight and curved. Uses: For cutting of bone. Option: D. Gigley’s saw Components: –– Braided stainless steel wire with a loop at the ends –– Two hooks. Uses: –– For amputation of the limb –– Used for osteotomy like Salter’s and McMurray’s osteotomy.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mallet It is an orthopedic hammer with a handle and cylindrical head. Uses: It is a companion instrument of osteotome, chisel, gouge, etc. Used for insertion of some implants such as nails (K-nail, V-nail, and Rush nail), plate (wein-wright plate), a prosthesis (Austin Moore), Steinmann pins, thick K-wires, etc. This is used for hammering different instruments like, chiesel, osteotome, while doingorthopaedicsurgeries.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION: A. Bone (Kocher’s) hook It is J shaped hooked instrument with a sharp or blunt tip, used for: Lifting of sagging bone fragments. Gentle pulling of fracture fragment buried in adjacent soft tissue. Option: B. Wrench or Spanner It is a tool with a long handle for taking advantage of torque with jaws and holes at its two ends. Types of spanners: Open-end type Box end type Combination of open and box type Option: D. Bone filler It features mesh-like serrations on its body. Useful for reshaping uneven or jagged edges of bone that may harm the adjacent soft tissue.

questions.text: What surgical implant is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herbert Screw A cannulated headless screw. The differential pitch between the leading (3 mm) and the trailing (3.9 mm) end produces a lag effect. Provide interfragmentary compression. Uses: For scaphoid fracture. Capitellum fracture. Radial head fracture. Talus fracture. Small joint arthrodesis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. & B. Cortical bone screws have a fine pitch; cancellous bone screws have a coarse pitch. The finer the pitch, the more turns the surgeon will have to make to insert the screw and the more turns of the spiral thread engage in a given depth of cortex. Option: D. DHS sliding screw A cannulated headless screw with a lag effect. Provide interfragmentary compression. Screw dimensions are as: Screw length: 50–130 mm Core diameter: 8 mm Thread length: 22 mm Thread diameter: 12.5 mm The shaft is rectangular with a rounded corner in a transverse section that fits in a similar slot of a barrel of DHS plate; it prevents the rotation of the screw in the barrel and finally stabilizes the fracture. DHS compression screw: It compresses the distal fragment of fracture over the proximal one. Length of the screw—36 mm. Diameter of screw—4 mm.

questions.text: Which type of implant is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Austin Moore prosthesis Austin Moore prosthesis – the implant given in the image has fenestrations, absent in its counterpart Thompson prosthesis, bone growth occurs through fenestrations aid anchorage to the bone.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Thompson’s prosthesis – This hip prosthesis is devoid of fenestrations, calcar is present in Thompson's prosthesis Option: C. Modular Bipolar Prosthesis – Has a special design with an outer and inner head, The additional joint between the outer shell and head of the prosthesis reduces implant erosion Option: D. Neer’s shoulder prosthesis – implant used in shoulder replacement surgeries

questions.text: A 28-year-old male came with an RTA and suffered a fracture of the right femur shaft. He was immobilized in Thomasa's splint with traction. Traction is used for all the conditions except?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction of fractures and dislocations and their maintenance

options.label: B
options.text: Immobilising a painful fracture and joint

options.label: C
options.text: Prevention of deformity by counteracting the muscle spasms

options.label: D
options.text: All the above statements are true

questions.correct_answer: D. All the above statements are true
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above statements are true When a limb is painful as a result of inflammation of a joint or a fracture of one of the bones, the controlling muscles contract simultaneously. This is called muscle spasm. The antagonistic muscles in a limb are not all equally powerful, with the result that when muscle spasm is present, the action of the more powerful muscles can produce a deformity that may seriously impair the future function of the limb. Traction, by overcoming muscle spasms, relieves pain and thus allows a limb to be rested in the best available In addition, traction reduces the movement of an injured part of the body and thus aids in the healing of bone and soft tissues. So, traction is done after most of the fractures. Traction is used for- Option A: 1). Reduction of fractures and dislocations and their maintenance Option B. 2). Immobilizing a painful fracture and inflamed joints. Option C. 3). Prevention of deformity by counteracting the muscle spasms 4). Correction of soft tissue contractures by stretching.
